question: Question_09
statement:
Find the singular values of $A=\begin{pmatrix}
1 &0 \\
1& 0\\
0&1
\end{pmatrix}$

Then determine the diagonal matrix $\Sigma$ in the singular value
decomposition A =$U\Sigma V^{T}$.
sols:
Given $A=\begin{pmatrix}
1 &0 \\
1& 0\\
0&1
\end{pmatrix}$ and $A^{^{T}}=\begin{pmatrix}
1 &1 &0 \\
0&0 &1
\end{pmatrix}$ we calculate $A^{T}A=\begin{pmatrix}
2 &0 \\
0&1
\end{pmatrix}$, which has the eigenvalues \emph{2} and \emph{1}. Hence,
the singular values of \emph{A} are $\sqrt{2}$ and $\displaystyle 1$.

Putting the singular values on the diagonal of \emph{Σ} we find that
$\Sigma =\begin{pmatrix}
\sqrt{2} &0 \\
0&1 \\
0&0
\end{pmatrix}.$
hints:
The singular values of \emph{A} are the square root of the eigenvalues
of \emph{A\textsuperscript{T}A}.

The matrix \emph{Σ} has the same dimension as \emph{A} and holds the
singular values on the diagonal.
